prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since the main goal of this survey is to image the dust continuum, we will configure the bands to 1.875 GHz bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity. The primary band is placed on the 12CO line with 0.8 km/s resolution, sufficient to resolve the spectral lines, which will extend over a few km/s. The remaining three bands were placed in continuum mode in portions of the band 7 with the highest atmospheric transmission to optimize continuum sensitvity.

We request a resolution of 0.08 arcseconds, which corresponds to configuration C36-6n. We need this resolution to resolve and measure the surface density profile of these disks, which may be as small as ~10-20 AU in radius. We simulated Cycle 3 observations for several antenna configurations, finding that we require the resolution of C36-6n to accurately determine both the surface density profile and radial extent of these disks. The maximum angular scale that is sampled by C36-6n is 1.4 arcsec, which may not cover the full extent of the disks. However, we will supplement our Cycle 3 data with our Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 observations of these stars with more compact configurations. We will thus achieve a maximum angular scale 5.2-15 arcseconds, more than enough to be sensitive to the entire disk. Given that Upper Sco is no longer embedded in a molecular cloud, there is no contamination from a dense molecular cloud to the gas and dust emission.

From our Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 observations, we know the 880 micron continuum flux of our targets. Given these flux densities, we simulated Cycle 3 observations to determine the sensitivity we would require for each source (see Figure 3 in Scientific Justification), finding that we need a signal to noise ratio of 100 to accurately fit the disk out radius and surface density profile. In each science goal, we set the requested sensitivity based on the requirements of the faintest source in that goal. For the Science Goal 3, containing our two faintest sources, we request less sensitivity due to the time requirements of achieving a signal to noise ratio of 100 for these two sources. In the sensitivity calculation, we assumed the full 7.5 GHz of bandwidth, since we set up the correlator with continuum sensitivity as the primary goal.
The focus of our proposal is detecting the dust continuum, therefore the are no sensitivity requirements for spectral lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The distribution of mass in protoplanetary disks, and how it evolves, controls the ability of disks to form planets. To study the structure of disks in detail, high resolution submillimeter observations of optically thin dust are required. We request time with ALMA to image the dust disks around eight M2-K2 (0.4-1.5 Msun) stars in the 5-11 Myr old Upper Scorpius OB Association (Upper Sco). With an age matching the timescale for disk dissipation, Upper Sco has become a benchmark for studying disk evolution. Using ALMA Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 observations of over 100 disks in Upper Sco, we have discovered that the majority of 5 Myr old disks are extremely faint (<10 mJy), with total dust masses of order 0.1 Mearth. The goal of this proposal is to use higher resolution, higher sensitivity observations to measure the surface density profiles of a subsample of these disks. The disks in this program represent typical disks around 5-11 Myr old Sun-like stars at the end state of their evolution. Thus, by determining the structure of these disks, we will place important constraints on how such disks dissipate.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
